user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_seek:
```c
lfs_soff_t lfs_file_seek(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file,
        lfs_soff_t off, int whence) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_seek(%p, %p, %"PRId32", %d)",
            (void*)lfs, (void*)file, off, whence);
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    lfs_soff_t res = lfs_file_seek_(lfs, file, off, whence);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_seek -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_seek:
static lfs_soff_t lfs_file_seek_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file,
        lfs_soff_t off, int whence) {
    // find new pos
    //
    // fortunately for us, littlefs is limited to 31-bit file sizes, so we
    // don't have to worry too much about integer overflow
    lfs_off_t npos = file->pos;
    if (whence == LFS_SEEK_SET) {
        npos = off;
    } else if (whence == LFS_SEEK_CUR) {
        npos = file->pos + (lfs_off_t)off;
    } else if (whence == LFS_SEEK_END) {
        npos = (lfs_off_t)lfs_file_size_(lfs, file) + (lfs_off_t)off;
    }

    if (npos > lfs->file_max) {
        // file position out of range
        return LFS_ERR_INVAL;
    }

    if (file->pos == npos) {
        // noop - position has not changed
        return npos;
    }

    // if we're only reading and our new offset is still in the file's cache
    // we can avoid flushing and needing to reread the data
    if ((file->flags & LFS_F_READING)
            && file->off != lfs->cfg->block_size) {
        int oindex = lfs_ctz_index(lfs, &(lfs_off_t){file->pos});
        lfs_off_t noff = npos;
        int nindex = lfs_ctz_index(lfs, &noff);
        if (oindex == nindex
                && noff >= file->cache.off
                && noff < file->cache.off + file->cache.size) {
            file->pos = npos;
            file->off = noff;
            return npos;
        }
    }

    // write out everything beforehand, may be noop if rdonly
    int err = lfs_file_flush(lfs, file);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // update pos
    file->pos = npos;
    return npos;
}
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
static lfs_soff_t lfs_file_seek_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file,
        lfs_soff_t off, int whence) {

lfs_off_t noff = npos;
int nindex = lfs_ctz_index(lfs, &noff);
explanation: I selected fragments where non-const pointer types are passed or accepted but appear to be used only for read-only purposes (or where unnecessary casts are applied), so they should be investigated for possible const qualification per MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Other code fragments were not reported because they clearly require mutable pointers or perform modifications and thus const-qualification would be inappropriate: - The top-level lfs_file_seek wrapper modifies or interacts with locking and passes the file object to functions that update its state (e.g. lfs_file_seek_ and lfs_file_flush), so its lfs_t* and lfs_file_t* parameters are plausibly non-const and need not be const. - Uses of file->pos, file->off, file->cache, and assignments to file->pos/file->off indicate the file object is intentionally mutated. - The LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK and LFS_TRACE macros involve config/state manipulation or logging (and use casts to (void*) for printing); those do not indicate missing const qualification. - Pointer expressions that clearly take the address of a local variable (e.g. &noff) where the callee may legitimately modify the pointed-to value are included only where ambiguity exists (lfs_ctz_index calls were included because we do not have its signature). - I avoided flagging trivial casts to (void*) for tracing and obvious mutations (e.g. calls that flush or update file state). If you want, I can further inspect the implementations or prototypes of lfs_ctz_index, lfs_file_size_, and lfs_file_flush to determine whether their pointer parameters could be const-qualified and update the suspicious list accordingly.
